elements.text: PAUL McGANN Time-space traveller
JULIE COX A newly acquired travelling companion
Owner of The Silver Turk, 30s. Clever, obsequious, scared.
50s. Theatrical, bushy-beared, heavyweight.
A Viennese Cabby, 20s. Spry, worldly, good-hearted.
A ruined Viennese Aristocrat, 20s. Impetuous, headstrong.
Count Rolf’s wife, 20s. Determined, wilful, motherly.
BREMM/GRAMM: NICHOLAS BRIGGS The eponymous Silver Turk; his friend. Both lost Cyberman.
THE EMPRESS ELISABETH (Sisi), LEOPOLD KRAUSS (an investor, 40s), POLICEMAN, WAITER, HEINZ, MAN IN AUDIENCE, WOMAN IN AUDIENCE, MAID (HANNALORE), PUPPETS, BARKERS AT THE EXPOSITION
BARNABY EDWARDS
ALAN BARNES
DAVID RICHARDSON
NICHOLAS BRIGGS AND JASON HAIGH-ELLERY
© BIG FINISH PRODUCTIONS 2011
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 1
1. NURSERY
FX: AN INFANT WITTENMEIER MEWLS.
Ssh, ssh. There now. What’s all this noise? Where’s Hannalore gone? Not used to Mother at bedtime?
FX: MORE MEWLING.
Oh, there now. Ssh...
SINGS A LULLABY TO THE TUNE OF Silent Night (Stille Nacht
Hush-a-bye, hush,
Nobody’s there.
No-one in the rocking chair. Flour on the floor
And blood on the stair,
Open the door
But the pantry is bare. Something’s cooking toni-ight. What can be cooking tonight?
FX: SEGUE INTO FOOTSTEPS ON AN EMPTY STREET
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 2
2. EXT. EMPTY BACK STREET.
FX: COBBLED STREET VIENNESE BACKSTREET IN 1873. EARLY EVENING.
DASH UP, PAUSE AS THE TERRIFIED LEOPOLD KRAUSS
HIS BREATH. A HORSE-DRAWN HACKNEY CAB (AN OPEN-TOPPED
FIAKER) CAN BE HEARD APPROACHING. THE FOOTSTEPS OF THE
CLIP-CLOP SLOW, REGULAR &
LIKE THEY’RE SHOD IN WOODEN SHOES, NOT METAL ONES)
Oh, Thank God... (STEPPING TOWARDS THE CAB) Cabbie! Cabbie!
FX: THE CAB DRAWS UP & THE HORSE SNORTS, AGAIN IN AN ODDLY
FASHION. DROSSEL IS AT THE REINS.
Good evening, sir.
The Stephansplatz... Quickly!
FX: KRAUSS OPENS THE DOOR AND STRUGGLES INSIDE.
Quickly!
The Stephanplatz, sir?
Yes! Now for pity’s sake get on with it!
You are Leopold Krauss?
What if I am? Dammit, man, get a move on — I’m being pursued!
These are hard times, Herr Krauss.
Here: take your fare now. (HE HANDS OVER TWO GOLD COINS. STILL THE CAB DOESN’T MOVE) All right, I’1l1l double it. (TWO MORE COINS) Just drive!
FX: WITH A FLICK OF THE WHIP, THE CARRIAGE SETS OFF. SEGUE BACK
TO THE LULLABY.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt
3. NURSERY
FX: BABY GURGLES CONTENTEDLY.
SINGING
Hush-a-bye, hush,
What’s in the pan? Something’s bubbling
As quick as it can.
A spoonful of eyes
And a bowl full of eggs.
A handful of fingers,
An armful of legs.
That’s what’s cooking toni-ight. What can be cooking tonight?
Page 3
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 4
4. EMPTY STREET
FX: THE HORSE AND CARRIAGE GOING SLOWLY
Faster, damn you!
We have a mutual acquaintance, sir. One Alfred Stahlbaum.
Stahlbaum?
A beneficiary to us both.
(FX: THE CARRIAGE DRAWS TO A STOP. KRAUSS SENSES SOMETHING IS
WRONG)
Who the Hell are you?
I’m not Retribution, if that’s what you thought. Far from it. My sins are far too many. (HE WHISTLES)
FX: THE SCRABBLING CREATURE (GRAMM) APPROACHES DOWN THE ALLEY.
Dear God!
GIVES A CURDLED CAWING SOUND... LIKE A WORDLESS CYBERMAN.
What is that?
FX: A MUSICAL BOX WHIRRS & TAKES UP MITZI’'S LULLABY.
A better world. That’s what we want. To get back what we lost and make it better.
WHINES AGAIN AS IT BEGINS TO CLIMB ONTO THE CARRIAGE.
Monster! Freak! Leave me alone. Leave me alone! Aaargh!
FX: THE MUSICAL BOX CARRIES ON...
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 5
5. NURSERY
PICKING UP THE END OF THE TUNE
Who was cooked in the pa-an? Poor old Pumpernickel Man.
FX: THE MUSICAL BOX WHIRRS DOWN.
6. EXT. VIENNA STREET.
FX: A BUSY STRASSE. HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES TRUNDLE PAST. THE
GRINDS INTO EXISTENCE. THE DOOR OPENS, THE DOCTOR AND
EMERGE. IT’S 1873, BUT THE DOCTOR THINKS IT’S 1816.
Erm... Frankfurt?
Frankfurt! Mary Shelley, have you ever been to Frankfurt?
No.
Obviously.
(FLUSTERED) Oh, I don’t know... Stuttgart?
No. But getting warmer.
Prague?
Cold again... Oh, come on.
Is it Germany?
Not exactly.
Oh... Austria?
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 6
Maybe.
Then we must be in... Salzburg?
Nearly.
Innsbruck?
No...
Oh, I give up. No, no, I don’t. I didn’t mean that.
Think. Austria... Kaffee und Kuchen. Waltzes...
Vienna!
At last! Well done!
(GIGGLING SLIGHTLY AT THE MADNESS OF IT) We’re in Vienna? Really? But we can’t be.
Just a short jump. Just to start off with.
No. That makes no sense.
Yes.
But an hour since we were beside Lake Geneva. In a different country. Vienna was hundreds of miles away.
Mere peanuts.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 7
But it’s impossible... so quickly. (SUDDENLY LESS FRIVOLOUS) Have I been abducted?
Not exactly. Don’t you remember anything I said? The marvels of the universe?
I’m not sure I trust what I remember. There’ve been nights like this before. Too much laudanum.
Not a good thing. To reiterate. I’m the Doctor.
(A STATEMENT, NOT A QUESTION) Not the monster.
Not the monster. And we came here in the TARDIS. My “blue hut.”
(REMEMBERING) But you said you’d leave Vienna for the moment. Your friends could wait, you declared. Gemma and Samson.
Well... I felt guilty. And I was trying to break you in gently.
Where else can your machine travel?
Steady now. We’ve only just got here. Don’t you want take in the sights?
Well, yes...
Excellent. So shall we walk or take a cab?
But...
Oh, walk I think. We need the fresh air.
Yes, Doctor.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 8
(SETTING OFF) The Café Demel isn’t far. (OFF) Well, come on.
Oh... Sorry.
FX: SHE DASHES TO CATCH UP & THEY WALK. WE GO WITH THEM.
We’ve only travelled in space this time, so it’s still the same year. 1816.
The same year?
Same day, week and month actually. Your friends at the Villa Diodati won’t even have missed you yet. (THEY STOP WALKING) Let’s leave the complications of travel in time for later.
To travel in time.. Forgive me... That’s not easy to follow.
I did try to explain.
More in the manner of a magician than a scientist.
I thought you’d say I was mad.
(DISMISSING THIS AS NONSENSE) Doctor!
That’s good. First rule for a companion. Whenever you’re in trouble, which you undoubtedly will be, that’s what you shout.
Doctor?
I’ll leave the circumstances to your discretion. But not too often, please. It gets a bit wearing. Right. Vienna. Hot chocolate is called for. The Café Demel. We have friends to meet.
FX: THEY STRIDE OFF
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 9
7. VIENNA EXPOSITION. STAHLBAUM’S EXHIBIT — BACKSTAGE
ROLF WITTENMEIER, A DESPERATE MAN, AND ALFRED STAHLBAUM, ‘CREATOR’ OF THE FAMED SILVER TURK, ARE ARGUING.
FX: SEVERAL CLOCKS ARE TICKING. IN THE NEXT ROOM, STAHLBAUM’S
AUTOMATON, THE TURK ITSELF, PRACTISES SCALES UP AND DOWN A PIANO. SOULLESS, RELENTLESS.
No, no, Count. I told you. Remuneration is out of the question.
I need the money back now, Stahlbaum! They warned me not to trust you.
Who? Who told you that?
Were they wrong?
Your investment in my project was accepted with gratitude. Interest will be paid at the appropriate time.
Will you see my wife and child on the streets, forced to live in penury?
Times are hard, Count, for all of us. People are not visiting the Exposition. Not since the Crash.
I lost everything. Do you know what that’s like? The Wittenmeiers have a household to maintain. I need my money now!
I am pursuing other sources of patronage. I have contacts at the Hofburg.
The Royal Family? Why would they care? Where’s your creation?
Through here?
FX: ROLF MOVES ACROSS THE ROOM.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 10
(HURRYING TO PREVENT HIM) Count!
FX: ROLF PULLS BACK A CURTAIN. THE PIANO IS MOMENTARILY LOUDER...
THEN STOPS. THE AUTOMATON IS A WORK OF UTTER BEAUTY.
(IMPRESSED) The Silver Turk. The automaton. All Vienna will talk of this mechanical wonder, Stahlbaum. That’s what you said.
Don’t stop. Continue your practice.
FX: A WHIRR OF CLOCKWORK. THE TURK STARTS PLAYING THE SLOW
OPENING OF BEETHOVEN’S MOONLIGHT SONATA.
Piano playing too?
It has many talents.
Remarkable. It moves like a living man, yet under these silks I’1l warrant... (REACHING FORWARD TO PULL UP THE SLEEVE & REVEAL THE CLOCKWORK )
Please... don’t touch!
(IN A HARDER TONE) I should take it now. Sell it off!
No! No... What good would that do? The Turk will make our
fortune. In time.
I need money now.. my family... my reputation!
FX: THE MUSIC WINDS ON.
(CHANGING THE SUBJECT) You like a challenge, don’t you, Count?
Of course you do. I’ve seen you at the gaming tables.
Not anymore. My gambling days are behind me.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 11
I saw you beat Count Larisch one time. The house was agog at your skills.
That was at cards, not chess. Or has your little clockwork companion learnt some new tricks?
The Turk has many accomplishments. Name your game.
What nonsense!
House rules. I cannot pay you back directly. Not now. But if you were to beat the Turk...
A game? For my loan to you?
Your loan repaid in full — if you beat the Turk in a public game, that is.
FX: FOR A BEAT, THE MUSIC STOPS.
And if I fail?
Oh come, Count. The Turk’s next appearance is this afternoon. You’11l draw a crowd. A paying crowd. What can you possibly lose?
FX: THE TURK RESUMES ITS SCALES.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 12
8. CAFE DEMEL
(FX: A BUSY VIENNESE CAFE, WITH MUTED CHATTER FROM AN ELEGANT CLIENTELE. THE DOCTOR SPINS A COIN ON THE WOODEN TABLE. HE BRINGS THE PALM OF HIS HAND DOWN TO FLATTEN THE COIN)
They’re late.
Your friends?
Gemma and Samson. No sense of time either of them. Maybe we should order. Waiter!
(AT A DISTANCE) Sir.
(PICKING UP THE MENU) I can’t decide what to have.
You’re probably still a bit disoriented. I’d recommend the Sachertorte, but it hasn’t been invented yet.
Do you always talk in riddles?
You are ready to order, sir?
Yes, please. Mary?
Oh... the apple strudel and coffee, bitte.
Danke.
And... gingerbread with a hot chocolate, please.
Thank you, sir.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 13
My German must be improving. Percy tells me I’1ll never master it, but suddenly everything makes sense.
Travel broadens the mind.
We will be back by evening, won’t we?
Back?
At the Villa? Can you work the trick in reverse?
Mary, we can be away for months and still home for supper on the day you left. Well, hopefully.
Doctor, you are the strangest man. I am almost alarmed by you.
Really?
Will all journeys be like this? So... instantaneous.
In the TARDIS, yes. Think of it as the Grand Tour to end all Grand Tours.
Without the scenery in between? But then they aren’t like journeys at all.
Scenery?
No impassable roads or mountains to cross. No exotic peasants
staring and pointing. No glaciers or brigands.
Ah...
The travelling. Surely that is the point.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 14
It’s a different sort of travel. You’1ll get used to it. Most friends of mine jump at the chance.
I shall defer judgement on that.
You are a very considered young lady.
That’s not what Percy says.
Well, he’d certainly know. Now, while we wait for Gemma and Samson to grace us with their presence... what would you like to see here in Vienna?
FX: HE PASSES HER A NEWSPAPER.
Take a look through the paper and see what you fancy. There must be a What’s On section.
I wish they’d hurry with the order.
Do you fancy waltzing? There’s always some extravagant ball coming up. The Viennese love waltzing almost as much as they love cake.
“AK second eyeless murder on the Ringstrasse.” Ooh...
It’s ages since I went waltzing...
It’s so strange. I can read German words that I don’t even
know. Ah... Doctor? The date on the newspaper.
What about it?
(POINTEDLY) The eleventh of September...
Ah...
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt
Not June.
No wonder it’s nippy out there.
Eighteen hundred and seventy-three?
Right. May I see that?
FX: HE TAKES THE PAPER.
Thank you.
That’s not the date you told me.
Page 15
Well, of course I could point out that you can’t always believe
what you read in the papers... but in this case.
Is it true? Are we really half a century into the future? 1873?
Maybe I overshot the mark a bit. Mary, I apologise. There probably is sachertorte after all.. I wonder what happened to
Gemma and Samson?
Obviously they decided not to wait.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 16
9. STAHLBAUM’S EXHIBIT. PERFORMANCE AREA.
FX: IN A TEMPORARY WOODEN EXHIBITION ROOM, A SMALL AUDIENCE
WATCHES A GAME OF DRAUGHTS BETWEEN COUNT ROLF AND THE SILVER TURK. A DRAUGHT CLICKS ONCE ON THE BOARD. THE AUDIENCE MUTTERS.
Let’s see what you make of that.
A clever move from Count Wittenmeier, ladies and gentlemen.
Another red checker taken.
FX: A CLOCKWORK WHIRR. ONE CLICK ON THE BOARD. THE AUDIENCE
“Oohs...”
The Turk counters. That is most ingenious. But how will the
Count respond?
FX: BEAT. A CHECKER CLICKS. WHIRR. THE TURK CLICKS A CHECKER
ONCE, TWICE. THE AUDIENCE “Ooohs.” SOME SPORADIC APPLAUSE.
Two more black checkers taken...
I won’t be beaten.
And the Turk makes another King. The Count’s position is in the
gravest jeopardy.
That’s what you’re meant to think.
FX: HE CLICKS THE BOARD THREE TIMES.
To me, I believe.
FX: CROWD “aahhs.” MORE POLITE APPLAUSE.
That surprised you.
FX: THE TURK WHIRRS. A CHECKER CLICKS MECHANICALLY FIVE TIMES
MOUNTING AUDIENCE AMAZEMENT.
No!
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 17
FX: AUDIENCE APPLAUSE.
Ladies and gentlemen, the Silver Turk wins the match!
It’s a trick! A sham!
Please, Count. (TO THE CROWD) Ladies and gentlemen, I assure you.. as you have seen...
It’s a lie!
It was a fair match. Please show you’re your appreciation for
the gallant loser!
You stole my money! You’re a thief! He’s a thief!
FX: HE LUNGES AT STAHLBAUM.
Unhand me!
I demand satisfaction!
Heinz! Throw him out!
FX: ROLF IS GRABBED AND CARRIED OUT STRUGGLING.
(CARRIED OUT) I demand satisfaction! I demand it!
FX: THE CROWD ARE LEAVING.
(RATTLED) Ladies and gentlemen, the show is over. I apologise.
Many apologies. So sorry. Such a bad loser. Please, clear the room. Thank you.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 18
9A. EXT. VIENNA EXPOSITION GROUNDS/TENT.
FX: COUNT ROLF IS THROWN TO THE GROUND. PEOPLE MILLING.
Next time, it’1ll be the police.
STRUGGLING UP, DESPAIRING) Ruffians! Thieves! (TO HIMSELF
Where now? Who’1ll listen now? No one listens.
FX: HE STUMBLES AWAY
10. EXT. EXPOSITION GROUNDS
FX: LIGHT CROWD OF PEOPLE MILLING. DISTANT STEAM TRAIN WHISTLE
(DISTANT, THROUGH THE MELEE) This way to the Grand Theatre of Marionettenburg! Dancing, singing, no strings attached!
(SCATTERED UNDER DIALOGUE) This way to the tearooms / Visit the Temple of Kyoto / Ladies and Gentlemen, the Machine Hall is open / British Biscuits — at the Emporium now!
The Vienna Exposition. That was an unexpected extra. Maybe 1873 isn’t such a bad year after all. Thanks for paying at the café by the way. And the entrance fee.
Don’t you ever carry any money? The head waiter was not amused.
He couldn’t resist your charms. Oh come on, Mary. You’1ll enjoy it. All the trade and advancement of the Western World is gathered here. It’s the future — well, your future anyway.
I’1l admit the Rotunda and Industrial Palace are tantalising prospects. Very well. Let’s start there.
You're on. Anyway, you’re a writer of science fiction. Think how useful it’1l be.
“Science fiction?’ I’m not sure I even know what that is.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 19
11. EXPOSITION GROUNDS/TENT
FX: PEOPLE MILLING. A DISTANT FAIRGROUND ORGAN PLAYS A MERRY
AN OOMPAH WALTZ-TIME VERSION OF ‘SILENT NIGHT.’ THE CLACK OF PUPPETS DANCING.
(SHOUTS) Thieves! Cheats! That’s it! All turn away! Nobody look! Turn away from the pfennig-less madman!
FX: MUSIC CONTINUES.
My friend.
Let me be!
No, no, my friend. Let me help you.
No-one helps me!
It’s Count Wittenmeier, isn’t it?
What’s that to you?
Here, take my arm.
What for? There’s nothing for you here.
Come along. Lean on me. (THEY WALK) That’s it. In here. Safer in my tent.
FX: HE PUSHES UP A CANVAS FLAP AND THEY ENTER A TENT.
Sit down, sit down.
FX: ROLF SLUMPS DOWN ON A WOODEN BENCH.
What do you want?
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 20
These are hard times, Count. Help each other, that’s a good rule.
People take... but they never give back.
Lost it all, eh? And who’s to blame?
Stahlbaum. Alfred Stahlbaum. Him and his machines.
Oh, yes. Stahlbaum the Great Showman. Took you for a ride, did he?
Took me to ruin.
No surprise there. He sets his sights high... always chooses the wealthy and easily led.
What?
You’re not the first, believe me. We all have our scars. But never fear, Count, I’1ll make sure he pays for his sins. And you can help me.
Help you?
(WHISTLES) Columbinetta!
FX: TENT FLAP OPENS. A CLATTERING WOODEN PUPPET ENTERS.
An automaton?
Columbinetta, fetch in our watchdog.
FX: THE PUPPET CLATTERS AWAY.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 21
So you’re a showman, too? A theatrical?
Of a sort, Count. Although my theatre is altogether out of this world.
FX: THE CLATTERING PUPPET APPROACHES
Ah. Columbinetta returns — with our watchdog.
FX: THE SCUTTLING MONSTER GRAMM APPEARS.
CYBER-WHINES
(HORRIFIED) God in Heaven... what is that?
My burden... my curse. Aren’t you, boy?
CYBERWHINES
Get it away from me!
It only wants you to play.
FX: GRAMM ADVANCES.
(IN TERROR) Get it away! Aaargh!
FX: A RIPPING OF CANVAS TO INDICATE TO THE PERCEPTIVE THAT ROLF
& ISN’T KILLED. THE FAIRGROUND ORGAN DROWNS OUT HIS SCREAMS.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 22
12. STAHLBAUM’S EXHIBIT
FX: BELLS JINGLE AT THE DOOR.
(NERVOUS) The exhibit is closed. The next appearance of the Silver Turk is at five o’clock!
FX: THE BELLS ARE REPEATED.
(OUTSIDE) Herr Stahlbaum! Please open the door!
Mitzi? Mitzi, is that you?
FX: HE OPENS THE DOOR.
My angel!
Countess Wittenmeier to you.
But Mitzi... dearest...
Is he here? My husband?
He was. About an hour ago.
What did he say?
Mitzi, it’s been four years.
I’m married now. I have a daughter, as you know. Where is the Count?
He was angry. He threatened me.
With good reason. He lent you money and received nothing in return. He’s already at his wit’s end. After the Crash, he lost everything.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 23
I asked him to leave. I can’t help him now.
Then where is he? I don’t know what he’1l do.
FX: SCALES START ON THE PIANO IN THE NEXT ROOM.
Who’s that playing? You have someone else here!
Mitzi.. you must leave Vienna. It’s not safe here.
You’re scared. Who is that?
Come away with me. We’1ll leave tomorrow. I’ve one more show to
finish.
I have a child now!
(HE GRABS HER) You have influence. Friends in the royal circle.
(SHAKING OFF HIS GRASP) Don’t touch me! Where’s my husband?
Gone. He left.
Where?
Why should I care?
Because I do. I fear for his life.
FX: SHE LEAVES.
Mitzi! Wait! Wait! Be careful!
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 24
13. EXPOSITION GROUNDS
FX: CROWDS
A cab ride, sir? Fraulein?
Not today, thank you.
Once round the Ringstrasse, in the most comfortable of carriages. All the landmarks, the Opera House, the Hofburg...
No, thank you. We have only recently arrived.
Then a tour is a necessity. To get your bearings. Which hotel are you staying at?
You’ve been following us. In your cab.
Keeping a watchful eye. Can’t be too careful these days.
Has he?
Ever since we left the café.
Even into the Exhibition?
I’m yours for however long you stay in Vienna, sir. Any time.
You’re English, yes?
Are we that obvious?
He’s very persistent. Perhaps we should... [accept his offer]
Mary, we do not need a guide.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 25
Who’s paying? Anyway, my shoes are starting to pinch.
Ernst Bratfisch at your service, Fraulein. Cab-driver to the nobility.
Business is hardly booming, I take it, Bratfisch?
Not since the Stock Market Crash, no, sir. The Exposition is not drawing the crowds. Not like they planned it.
And the recent attacks?
Attacks?
In the paper. Front page.
Oh... Yes.. Were the victims’ eyes really gouged out?
Mary!
Grisly business, Fraulein. Better not to walk. Not after dark.
And no-one saw anything. Well, no.. they wouldn’t, would they? Obviously.
If that was a jest, Doctor, it was in very poor taste. You’re
as bad as Percy.
But you’ve noticed nothing strange?
(SUSPICIOUS) You a policeman? Or some sort of an investigator?
This is purely my own curiosity. So what have you seen?
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 26
Well... there was rumours round the city. That’s how it started.
Rumours?
Plenty. Put the wind up some of the drivers, I can tell you.
And?
I wouldn’t want to alarm the Fraulein.
Alarm her! This is Mary Shelley you’re talking to. Author of the darkest, spookiest stories you could ever read.
Am I?
They scared the pants off me!
Well... er... that’s good to know. Continue your narrative, sir.
Well, I didn’t believe the stories, Fraulein, not ‘til two nights back. That was when I saw it. Halfway down Wolfstrasse by the river.
Saw what? What did you see?
FX: THE EXPOSITION SOUNDS FADE.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 27
13A. FLASHBACK INSERT
FX: SLOW SOUND OF HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGE APPROACHING AND PASSING.

It was a black carriage — a fiaker — coming towards us. Slowly it went, more like a hearse... and its horses were strange... glossy... walking all wrong... clop... clip... clop... Their hooves sounded like they had wooden shoes.
And the driver?

That was it.. there was no driver. The seat was empty. No sign of passengers neither. But blimey, those two nags knew where they were going. And as they passed me, the lamplight caught their eyes. And they were blue!
Blue?
Not right, was it? Not for horses.
But you followed them.
Strewth, d’you think I hung about. I drove my own pair for home like the old devil himself was after us. (WE BEGIN THE
OUT OF THE FLASHBACK AND BACK TO THE EXPOSITION) Shift yourself, Fraulein!
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 28
13B. EXT. EXPOSITION GROUNDS
FX: BACK INTO THE EXPOSITION WITH A CRUNCH AS MITZI COLLIDES
WITH MARY.
Shift my what? (MITZI COLLIDES WITH HER) Ouch!
Oh, sorry. (WEEPING) I was just... I’m so sorry.
Are you alright?
Yes... yes.. I’m fine.
Are you sure?
I was looking... My husband... I can’t find him.
In the beer tent, I expect.
(IGNORING THIS REMARK) Where did you last see him? I’m sure he can’t have gone far.
(THROUGH SOBS) I don’t know. He was distressed. I don’t know where he went. He left home in a temper. And I’m so afraid for him.
And you followed him here?
Did you have a disagreement?
No. He had business here. Private business.
FX: IN THE DISTANCE THE PUPPET SHOW STARTS AGAIN.
Beg pardon, ma’am, but aren’t you the Countess Wittenmeier?
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt
(SLIGHTLY TAKEN ABACK AT BEING RECOGNIZED) Yes... yes,
Page 29
I am.
(AWKWARD) Well, ma’am. I carried the Count a few times. And I
saw him this afternoon.
Here? At the Exposition? When?
Not fifteen minutes since. In a proper lather, he was
at the crowd... swinging at folks... and then the police
The police!
Carted him off. Like they’d been looking for him.
They arrested him?
But for what?
Well, at least we know he’s safe.
My husband’s not a villain.
Then we’ll go and find him, bail him out.
Oh, no. You’re very kind, but you’re visitors.

DARK CHORD.
THE END.
WHO - THE SILVER TURK by Marc Platt Page 160
A few of thoughts about the characters:

Drossel - lifted from Drosselmeyer, who is the clockmaker/inventor in Hoffman's The Nutcracker and the Mouse King (and the ballet too.) Our Drossel also has some traits lifted from Coppelius in Hoffman's The Sandman, where he collects and sells "pretty eyes", but in that case, rather less gruesomely, they are spectacles. The puppet-master side of him is rather more like Stromboli, the big- bearded theatre man in Pinocchio.

Stahlbaum - is the family name of Clara, the heroine of the Nutcracker. Bratfisch - the historical Josef Bratfisch was private cabdriver to Crown Prince Rudolf, the son of Empress Elizabeth, who committed suicide at Mayerling in 1889. But this, of course is 1873, so Ernst was probably Josef's Uncle - the one the family don't talk about!
The Wittenmeiers are entirely fictitious.
The Empress was originally going to be the real Empress Elizabeth, but it was
much more fun (and crueller) to make her another puppet. Sisi was her established nickname.

DOCTOR: A few of thoughts about the characters:
DOCTOR: Drossel - lifted from Drosselmeyer, who is the clockmaker/inventor in Hoffman's The Nutcracker and the Mouse King (and the ballet too.) Our Drossel also has some traits lifted from Coppelius in Hoffman's The Sandman, where he collects and sells "pretty eyes", but in that case, rather less gruesomely, they are spectacles. The puppet-master side of him is rather more like Stromboli, the big- bearded theatre man in Pinocchio.
DOCTOR: Stahlbaum - is the family name of Clara, the heroine of the Nutcracker. Bratfisch - the historical Josef Bratfisch was private cabdriver to Crown Prince Rudolf, the son of Empress Elizabeth, who committed suicide at Mayerling in 1889. But this, of course is 1873, so Ernst was probably Josef's Uncle - the one the family don't talk about!
DOCTOR: The Wittenmeiers are entirely fictitious.
DOCTOR: The Empress was originally going to be the real Empress Elizabeth, but it was
DOCTOR: much more fun (and crueller) to make her another puppet. Sisi was her established nickname.
